I see Martin (but who else?) saved everyone the pain (or in the alternative spoiled the fun for everyone) from guessing an obscure face in American history. What I liked about the quote is that “I surrender” is not the same as back down. And this is the rest of the story from Wikipedia.

Oliver Prince Smith (October 26, 1893 – December 25, 1977) was a General in the United States Marine Corps and a highly decorated combat veteran of World War II and the Korean War. He is most noted for commanding the 1st Marine Division during the Battle of Chosin Reservoir, where he said "Retreat, hell! We're not retreating, we're just advancing in a different direction." He retired at the rank of four-star general, being advanced in rank for having been specially commended for heroism in combat.

To be continued...

Continued...

In October 1950, the 1st Marine Division landed at Wonsan on the eastern side of Korea under the command of the Army's X Corps commanded by Edward Almond. Almond and Smith shared a mutual loathing of each other that dated back to a meeting between the two in Japan before the landing at Inchon. During the meeting Almond had spoken of how easy amphibious landings were although he had never planned or taken part in one and then referred to Smith as Son although he was only 10 months older than he was. Smith and the Marine command also felt Almond was overly aggressive and were sure that there were large numbers of Chinese Forces in North Korea when higher headquarters in Tokyo was telling them it was not the case. Although ordered to go north to the Yalu River as fast as he could, Smith continuously slowed the division's march to the point of near insubordination. Also along the way he established supply points and an airfield.

In November 1950, with the 1st Marine Division surrounded at the Chosin Reservoir, he directed the breakout and subsequent 70 miles (110 km) march to the seaport of Hungnam. In the end his careful march north and ability to keep the division together saved it from total destruction and quite possibly the entire X Corps.

So because he owns "serious" firearms he is the liar here? That is preposterous and insulting. There is no connection by default, and your apologism is sad. It doesn't matter whether he was or was not a sniper ... it was Pellegrin who falsely portrayed him as something he isn't, either intentionally or through negligence, to fatten up his essay rather than just make legitimate photos of criminal gun users.

And what does his being "a kid in his 20s" have to do with anything? Remember Woodward and Bernstein? Woodward was 31 when Watergate broke, and had about a year's journalism experience. Bernstein was only a bit older. Your post is absurd on its face. And should I draw any conclusion from the fact that you, Claudio, are leaping to the defense of Paolo? Or would that be as foolish as your focusing on the age of the whistle blower?

it's pretty amazing to me that many people here are willing to take completely at face value the account of a kid in his 20s who, by the way, stores serious rifles and pistols in his garage.  first of all - isn't that completely relevant to the story the photographer was trying to tell, and isn't it pretty shocking that no one is talking about it?  second, the photographer says he remembers the kid claiming to be a sniper - isn't it at least possible that he overplayed his machismo, did claim that, and is now embarassed because the picture won awards and he was caught in a lie, claiming to be a sniper when he was actually just a Marine photographer (not that there's anything wrong with that)?

While I agree there are some strong issues raised in this discussion, and certainly some sloppy journalism (at best) on the part of the photographer, the one issue I disagree with is the subject's non-relation to the story. Gun violence in poor neighborhoods begets gun ownership/protection in better off neighborhoods. While an ex-Marine isn't the best example, as I'm sure nearly all ex-Marines maintain weapons, the notion that a gun owner in a suburb near a dangerous neighborhood isn't somehow connected to that dangerous neighborhood through their ownership of weaponry is not very well thought out. I won't speak about Mr. Keller as I don't know him personally and of course Mr. Pellegrin should have asked him why he owns the weapons he does. But i can say with certainty that a decent percentage of suburban gun owners maintain the ownership for personal protection and that usually isn't for protection from their middle or upper class neighbors. Bravo to Gonzalez and Estrin for the thoroughly researched article. I would like to know Mr. Keller's thoughts on gun ownership in the suburbs and whether he believes this does or does not have any relation to gun violence in the city. Or are gun owners in the suburbs all just out there shooting at the range and/or squirrels for dinner?

From the Bureau of Labor Statistics/US Department of Labor:

October unemployment rate 2006: 4.4%
October unemployment rate 2007: 4.7%
October unemployment rate 2008: 6.5%
October unemployment rate 2009 10.2%

I wanted to thank you for your consistently reasonable tone in this debate. I really believe it makes what you say more likely to be heard than the angry comments, so many of which we've seen here.

You are right when you say that journalists are not prosecutors. To listen to both sides of an argument and halt judgement can be uncomfortable, but it's absolutely necessary. Our job is to strive to present as much information as we can within the bounds of the possible. It's all a process. I understand many people feel frustrated over this debate but I strongly believe that hurling insults and rushing to judgement won't help solve anything. Ping Fu has said she is willing to talk, but wants civility. Perhaps that's a good idea? I'm heartened to see you practicing that. It's just smart.

When Reagan was elected in 1980, corporate taxes contributed 20% of all Federal revenues...as you note its now 9%. This reduction has all gone to the 1% managerial/owner class (those small businessmen in GOP parlance) - the benefit has not gone to employees with flat incomes or to shareholders.. As you point out payroll taxes and income taxes contribute almost the same amount of revenue to the Federal budget. But since 2000 revenue from income tax has been flat, while revenue from payroll taxes has grown by about 30%. Payroll tax revenue would overtake income tax revenue had it not been for the recent increase in top rates.

While screaming for lower taxes, the GOP really only concerns itself with cutting corporate and income taxes while cutting payroll related benefits (entitlements). And, they have been getting away with it. There is a $3 trillion IOU to surplus Social Security taxes used for other purposes, even though George Bush & the GOP promised to put these funds in a lock-box for the future. Just think agricultural subsidies going to a very small segment of the economy (with no dedicated funding source) exceeds Federal transportation outlays supported by many dedicated tax streams.

'To each according to capacity, each according to need' utopia seen by Karl Marx as the communist stage of social evolution did also envisage a stateless and classless society with complete social control on the means of production and distribution through the creation of egalitarian conditions. With oligopoly control over wealth and resources, casualisation of labour, outsourcing of jobs, and driving out the working hands from job market, does contemporary America or any rich industrialised nation could fulfill the conditions Karl Marx had suggested for socialising labour and leisure? Moreover, work is not simply a means to earn subsistence livelihood, but equally a human need for realising one's own potential and creative self. Could Ross Douthat be sure about all this in the America placing 99% at the mercy of 1%? Why malign Marx, or trivialise a serious social reality then?
